text: was a after Shōhō and before Jōō. This period started in February 1648 and ended in September 1652.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Kei'an" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 503. During this time, the emperor was .Nussbaum, "Go-Kōmyō Tennō," p. 256; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, p. 412. ==Events of the Keian era== * 1648 (Keian 1): Legal code about city life and business are established in OsakaHall, John Whitney. Early Modern Japan, p. xx. * 1649 (Keian 2): Five-storied pagoda at was built in Asakusa.Nihon Gaiji Kyōkai. (1942). Contemporary Japan: a Review of Japanese Affairs, Vol. 11, Part 2, p. 749. * 1649 (Keian 2): Legal code for peasants established by Tokugawa Iemitsu.Nussbaum, "Kei'an no ofuregake" at p. 503. * 1 April 1649 (Keian 2, 20th day of the 2nd month): There was a major earthquake in Edo.Titsingh, p. 412. * 1651 (Keian 4): Plot to overthrow the Tokugawa, also known as the Keian Uprising.Nussbaum, "Kei'an jinken" at p. 503; Screech, Timon. (2006). Secret Memoirs of the Shogans: Isaac Titsingh and Japan, 1779-1822, pp. 85-89. * 1652 (Keian 5, 5th month): Nihon Odai Ichiran was published.Titsingh, pp. 406, 412. The French version of this work was the first Japanese history book to be published in the West. ==Related pages == * Edo period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Keian 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 1648 1649 1650 1651 1652 Preceded by: Shōhō Era or nengō: Keian Succeeded by: Jōō Category:Japanese eras Category:1648 establishments Category:17th-century establishments in Japan Category:1650s disestablishments in Japan
title: Keian
